Name: Brian P. Kemp
Other Roles: Georgia State Senator (2003–2007) | 27th Georgia Secretary of State (2010–2018)
Economic Policies: Recruit business investment to all regions of Georgia|Cut taxes for families and businesses|Maintain Georgia as the #1 state for business|Support small business growth and reduce regulatory burden
Political Priorities: Strengthening public safety and cracking down on violent crime|Ending human trafficking and supporting victims|Improving K-12 education and increasing teacher pay|Expanding economic opportunity in rural Georgia
Biography: Brian Porter Kemp is a native of Athens, Georgia, where he attended Athens Academy and Clarke Central High School before earning a degree in agriculture from the University of Georgia.|Before entering politics, Kemp worked as a small business owner, founding his own home building and development company — experience that has shaped his governing philosophy of putting hardworking Georgians first.|Kemp began his political career as a Georgia State Senator in 2003, serving until 2007. In 2010, he was appointed Georgia's 27th Secretary of State by Governor Sonny Perdue, a position he was elected to and held until 2018.|He was sworn in as Georgia's 83rd Governor on January 14, 2019, after narrowly defeating Democrat Stacey Abrams. During his first term, Georgia was named the No. 1 state for business for an unprecedented run of consecutive years.|In 2022, Kemp was re-elected to a second term, again defeating Stacey Abrams, this time by a wider margin. He and First Lady Marty Kemp have three adult daughters and live on their family farm in Athens.

Name: Donald J. Trump
Economic Policies: Slow inflation to make America affordable again|Large tax cuts for workers and no tax on tips|Cancel the electric vehicle mandate and cut costly and burdensome regulations
Political Priorities: Strengthen border security|Expanding domestic energy production|Supporting law enforcement|Rebuilding American manufacturing
Biography: Donald John Trump is an American businessman, television personality, and politician. He served as the 45th president of the United States from 2017 to 2021 and as the 47th president beginning in 2025.|Before entering politics, Trump was known for his real estate business, including hotels, golf courses, and commercial properties. He also gained national recognition as the host of the television show The Apprentice."

Name: Andre Dickens
Other Roles: Atlanta City Council At-Large Post 3 (2014–2021) | Chief Development Officer at TechBridge | Co-founder of Technology Career Program
Economic Policies: Establish 20,000 affordable housing units by 2030|Invest $58.7 million housing bond to create and preserve affordable housing|Historic $60 million Homeless Opportunity Bond to address homelessness|Attract balanced business growth across all neighborhoods including south and west Atlanta|$17.50/hr minimum wage for city employees and annual pay increases|$240 million Moving Atlanta Forward infrastructure package for roads and public spaces
Political Priorities: One Safe City: reduce crime through community-focused programs and the Nightlife Division|Light Up the Night: install 30,000 LED street lights to improve neighborhood safety|Youth development through Year of the Youth and Midnight Basketball League|Expand early childhood education investment|Achieve 100% clean energy and lead on climate resilience|Eradicate food deserts and improve neighborhood equity
Biography: Andre Peter Dickens was born on June 17 1974 in Atlanta Georgia. He grew up in the Adamsville neighborhood on the city's historic Westside where he attended Benjamin Elijah Mays High School before going on to earn a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology in 1998.|After graduating from Georgia Tech Dickens began his career as a sales engineer and became the youngest and first Black salesman of the year at
